overview: What happens if you become disabled - registering as a disabled person, benefits, your rights, help from your council and your employer's responsibilities
title: What to do if you become disabled

table.body:
If you become disabled, you have [rights](/rights-disabled-person/overview "disability rights") to protect you from discrimination. You also might be entitled to certain benefits. 

The main disability and sickness benefits are:

- [Disability Living Allowance (DLA)](/dla-disability-living-allowance-benefit "Disability Living Allowance")
- [Attendance Allowance](/attendance-allowance "Attendance Allowance")
- [Employment and Support Allowance](/employment-support-allowance "Employment and Support Allowance")

What you're entitled to depends on your circumstances - use the [benefits adviser](/benefits-adviser "benefits adviser") tool to see what you might be able to get.

To get any benefits you're entitled to, you need to register as a disabled person - there's more information about this on the [NHS Choices website.](http://www.nhs.uk/chq/pages/2571.aspx?categoryid=155&subcategoryid=155){:rel="external"}

You might also be able to get:

- certain types of equipment or have adaptations made to your home without paying [VAT](/vat/vat-on-equipment-for-disabled-people "VAT") 
- [Council Tax discounts](/council-tax/discounts-for-disabled-people "Council Tax discounts")
- a [TV licence discount](/free-discount-tv-licence "TV licence discount")
- a free [vehicle tax disc](/driving-if-disabled/tax-disc-exemptions "free vehicle tax disc")

^If you're in England you can get a [health and social care assessment](/apply-needs-assessment-social-services "health and social care assessment") to find out what help you can get (eg equipment, home care, day centres) from your local council.^




*[DLA]:Disability Living Allowance
table.title: Overview

table.body:
Your employer can't discriminate against you because of your disability - you're [protected by the Equality Act 2010](/rights-disabled-person/employment "disability rights at work"). 

They must also keep your job open for you and can't put pressure on you to resign just because you've become disabled. 

##Reasonable adjustments

Your employer must make 'reasonable adjustments' for you so that you're not disadvantaged compared to non-disabled people.

This could include:

- a phased return to work – eg working flexible hours or part-time
- time off for medical treatment or counselling
- giving another employee tasks you can't easily do
- providing practical aids and technical equipment for you

##Time off from work

If you're an employee and can't work because of your disability, you may be able to get [Statutory Sick Pay (SSP)](/statutory-sick-pay-ssp "Statutory Sick Pay"). Some employers have their own sick pay scheme instead.

If you still can't work after 28 weeks, or you can't get Statutory Sick Pay, you can apply for [Employment and Support Allowance](/employment-support-allowance "Employment and Support Allowance").

Time off from work should not be recorded as an 'absence from work' if you're waiting for your employer to put reasonable adjustments in place.

^Check your [employment status](/employment-status "employment status") if you're not sure whether you're an employee or not.^

##Dismissals and redundancy

Your employer can't dismiss you just because you've become disabled. 

You can be dismissed if your disability means you can't do your job even with reasonable adjustments. 

You can't be selected for [redundancy](/redundant-your-rights "redundancy your rights") just because you're disabled.

^For advice about work issues, talk to [ACAS](http://www.acas.org.uk/index.aspx?articleid=1410 "ACAS"){:rel="external"} (the Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service), [Citizens Advice](http://www.citizensadvice.org.uk/index/getadvice.htm "Citizens Advice"){:rel="external"} or your trade union representative.^

*[ACAS]: the Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service
*[SSP]: Statutory Sick Pay
